newsitem.title: POLAND: BANKS LEND POLISH PKP RAILWAYS PLN 633 MLN.
newsitem.headline: BANKS LEND POLISH PKP RAILWAYS PLN 633 MLN.

text.p: A consortium of five Polish banks agreed to lend the state PKP railways 633 million zlotys to buy 50 locomotives from Poland's Pafawag, clearing the take-over of Pafawag by Adtranz, the bank consortium leader said on Friday.

"Today we signed an agreement creating a loan consortium for 10 years and two agreements with Polish State Railways (PKP) for the purchase of 50 locomotives in Pafawag for a total of 633 million zlotys," said Krzysztof Szwarc, president of Bank Rozwoju Exportu SA (BRE), the bank leading the consortium.
He said the loan would consist of two tranches -- one for 285 million zlotys and the second for 165 million Swiss francs.
There are no government guarantees for the loans which have their interest based on one-month WIBOR for the zloty tranche and on one-month LIBOR for the currency tranche.
The five banks creating the consortium are: BRE, the Polish Development Bank (PBR), Pekao SA bank, Bank Handlowy SA and Powszechny Bank Kredytowy SA (PBK).
Szwarc said the loan for PKP cleared the way for the completion of the sale of 75 percent of Pafawag to Adtranz for for $3.7 million.
"Today, thanks to the PKP order...the sale of Pafawag to Adtranz can be finalised," he said.
In September Poland signed an initial agreement with Adtranz, a joint venture of ABB group and Daimler-Benz AG, to sell it the ailing rolling-stock maker Pafawag SA.

Adtranz agreed to bring modern technology to Pafawag and invest $28.1 million there over the next six years on the condition that the firm gets a locomotive delivery order from the Polish State Railways (PKP).

Adtranz would then increase Pafawag's capital by $6 million and launch the production of a high-speed state-of-the-art locomotive. Pafawag, which employes 1,620 people, is based in the south-western city of Wroclaw.
Head of Daimler Benz Transportation for Central Europe John Kapala, aslo present, said that formalities of Adtranz's takeover of Pafawag should be completed by the end of February.

PKP's director general Jan Janik said PKP welcomed the conditions of the contract. "This is the best contract we could get," he said, adding it was collateralised by PKP's locomotives, liquid assets and real estate.
PKP had a 71 million zloty net loss in 1995 and preliminary data showed 1996 results were worse, but Janik said the company expected to break even this year.
"Our financial situation is good, the overall debt is not higher than 50 percent allowed by the World Bank," Janik said.
